references:
We consider two different scenarios for training the local model. In the first scenario, referred as IoT device local learning, local models are trained at the IoT devices and the F-APs upload the collected local model parameters to the CS for aggregation. In the second scenario, referred as F-AP local learning, the local models are trained at the F-APs based on the collected data from the IoT devices.
For both scenarios, we aim at minimizing the overall energy consumption of IoT devices and F-APs subject to FL time constraint, IoT device-RRB/F-AP scheduling, transmit power allocations, and computation frequency allocation. Such a joint optimization problem is NP-hard and thus, computationally intractable. By analyzing the problem of each scenario, we decompose it into two subproblems namely, resource scheduling and power
allocation subproblem and computation frequency allocation subproblem.

Let 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} denote the local data set of IoT device n𝑛n, which is a set of data samples {xi,yi}subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖\{x_{i},y_{i}\}, where xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is sample i𝑖i’s input (e.g., image
pixels) and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is sample i𝑖i’s output (e.g., label of the image). Similar to [23, 25],
the local loss function on IoT device n𝑛n’s data set can be calculated as Ln​(ω)=1Dn​∑i∈𝒟nli​(ω),∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequencesubscript𝐿𝑛𝜔1subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑖subscript𝒟𝑛subscript𝑙𝑖𝜔for-all𝑛𝒩L_{n}(\omega)=\frac{1}{D_{n}}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{D}_{n}}l_{i}(\omega),\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, where Dn=|𝒟n|subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝒟𝑛D_{n}=|\mathcal{D}_{n}| is the number of collected data samples by IoT device n𝑛n and li​(ω)subscript𝑙𝑖𝜔l_{i}(\omega) is the loss function that measures the local training model error of data sample i𝑖i. Then, IoT device n𝑛n finds the optimum ωn∗subscriptsuperscript𝜔𝑛\omega^{*}_{n} that minimizes Ln​(ω)subscript𝐿𝑛𝜔L_{n}(\omega) and uploads it to the suitable F-APs for aggregation by the CS. The IoT devices independently train local ML models based on their aggregated local data (e.g., images, videos, recorded audios). As shown in
Fig. 1, the specific process of FL in the t𝑡t-th iteration can be summarized as: 1) each IoT
device downloads the global model parameters ωn​(t−1)subscript𝜔𝑛𝑡1\omega_{n}(t-1) from
the CS through the nearest F-AP; 2) each IoT device updates the local model by its
local training data and sends the updated local
model parameter ωn​(t)subscript𝜔𝑛𝑡\omega_{n}(t) back to the F-APs; and 3) the CS aggregates the information from the F-APs and calculates the
new global model parameters.

We propose to minimize the total energy consumption for a delay-constrained FL. Specifically, our proposed framework intelligently selects the active IoT devices that perform local learning and assigns active IoT devices to the suitable F-APs.
Considering IoT device local learning scenario, the energy minimization problem can be formulated as

Solving problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} owing to its mixed combinatorial characteristics is challenging. Although exhaustive
search and branch-and-bound approaches can obtain near-optimal solution to 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1}, such approaches are not suitable for the practical systems due to the significantly increased computational complexity. To strike a suitable balance between the required complexity and performance, we propose an iterative approach to solve problem P1 for large-scale IoT networks. To this end, we decompose 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} into the following two subproblems, namely, (i) IoT device scheduling and power allocation subproblem for a given IoT device’ computation frequency allocation, and (ii) IoT device’ computation frequency allocation subproblem for the determined power and IoT device scheduling.

𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is solved by iteratively solving both subproblems 𝒫3subscript𝒫3\mathcal{P}_{3} and 𝒫5subscript𝒫5\mathcal{P}_{5} until convergence. The overall algorithm to obtain a suitable solution to problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathcal{P}_{1} is provided in Section IV-C.

In subproblem 𝒫3−1subscript𝒫31\mathcal{P}_{3}-1, Rt​h,nsubscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑛R_{th,n} and Rt​h,jsubscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑗R_{th,j} are the required uplink data rates for the n𝑛n-th and j𝑗j-th IoT devices, respectively; and V𝑉V is a given weight factor. In particular, Rt​h,n=Tg​dnTq,k−Tg​Tl​Cn​Dnfn∗subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑛subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑑𝑛subscript𝑇𝑞𝑘subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛R_{th,n}=\frac{T_{g}d_{n}}{T_{q,k}-T_{g}T_{l}\frac{C_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}^{*}}} and Rt​h,j=Tg​djTq,k−Tg​Tl​Cj​Djfj∗subscript𝑅𝑡ℎ𝑗subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑑𝑗subscript𝑇𝑞𝑘subscript𝑇𝑔subscript𝑇𝑙subscript𝐶𝑗subscript𝐷𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑗R_{th,j}=\frac{T_{g}d_{j}}{T_{q,k}-T_{g}T_{l}\frac{C_{j}D_{j}}{f_{j}^{*}}}. Essentially, the rate constraints C8 and C9 satisfy the FL delay constraint C4. On the other hand, the weight factor V𝑉V is selected to strike a suitable balance between capacity and energy consumption of the vertices.

In 𝒫6subscript𝒫6\mathcal{P}_{6}, the optimization is over the continuous variables 𝐩𝐩\bf p, and the discrete variables ak,nsubscript𝑎𝑘𝑛a_{k,n}, and sk,zn,∀k∈𝒦,n∈𝒩,z∈𝒵formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscript𝑠𝑛𝑘𝑧for-all𝑘𝒦formulae-sequence𝑛𝒩𝑧𝒵s^{n}_{k,z},\forall k\in\mathcal{K},n\in\mathcal{N},z\in\mathcal{Z}. It is still difficult to solve problem 𝒫6subscript𝒫6\mathcal{P}_{6}
because of its non-convexity. To find a tractable solution to 𝒫6subscript𝒫6\mathcal{P}_{6}, we develop an efficient algorithm in Section V-B.

In our simulations, we consider a hexagonal cell of radius 150015001500 m where F-APs and CS have fixed locations and IoT devices are distributed randomly within the cell. The CS is
located at the cell center. The channel model for IoT device-F-AP transmissions follows the standard path-loss model, which consists of three components: 1) path-loss of 128.1+37.6​log10⁡(dis.[km])128.137.6subscript10dis.[km]128.1+37.6\log_{10}(\text{dis.[km]}); 2) log-normal shadowing with 444 dB standard deviation; and 3) Rayleigh channel fading with zero-mean and unit variance. The noise power, F-AP’s power, and maximum’ IoT device power are assumed to be −174174-174 dBm/Hz and qk=pmax=3subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑝max3q_{k}=p_{\text{max}}=3 W, respectively [25]. The weighting factor V𝑉V is set to 0.30.30.3. The total number of global and local FL iterations are calculated as Tg=2​β2(2​ϑ−β​η)​ϑ​η​ln⁡(1/ϵg)subscript𝑇𝑔2superscript𝛽22italic-ϑ𝛽𝜂italic-ϑ𝜂1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔T_{g}=\frac{2\beta^{2}}{(2\vartheta-\beta\eta)\vartheta\eta}\ln(1/\epsilon_{g}), Tl=2(2−δ​β)​δ​ϑ​ln⁡(1/ϵl)subscript𝑇𝑙22𝛿𝛽𝛿italic-ϑ1subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙T_{l}=\frac{2}{(2-\delta\beta)\delta\vartheta}\ln(1/\epsilon_{l}), respectively, with β=4,η=1/3,δ=1/4,ϑ=2,ϵg=ϵl=10−3formulae-sequence𝛽4formulae-sequence𝜂13formulae-sequence𝛿14formulae-sequenceitalic-ϑ2subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑙superscript103\beta=4,\eta=1/3,\delta=1/4,\vartheta=2,\epsilon_{g}=\epsilon_{l}=10^{-3} [21]. The FL time threshold Tqsubscript𝑇𝑞T_{q} is 111 second [21]. The bandwidth of each RRB is 202020 MHz. Unless otherwise stated, we set the numbers of F-APs and RRBs to 999 and 444, respectively. The fronthaul capacity Rf​hsubscript𝑅𝑓ℎR_{fh} is set to 150 Mbit/s. For each IoT device and each F-AP, the number of data samples Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} is randomly chosen from 800800800 to 100010001000. Other parameters are summarized in Table I. To assess the performance of our proposed scenarios, we simulate various scenarios with different number of IoT devices N𝑁N, data size 𝙳nsubscript𝙳𝑛\mathtt{D}_{n}, number of RRBs Z𝑍Z, number of data samples Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n}, computation frequency allocation fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}, fksubscript𝑓𝑘f_{k}, and parameter data size. For the sake of comparison, our
proposed schemes are compared with the following baseline schemes.

In Figs. 8-a and 8-a , we show the energy consumption
versus the number of CPU cycles for the first and second scenarios, respectively. The number of CPU cycles ranges from 2×1072superscript1072\times 10^{7} to 10×10710superscript10710\times 10^{7} in Fig. 8-(a) and from 2×1092superscript1092\times 10^{9} to 10×10910superscript10910\times 10^{9} in Fig. 8-(b). The number of CPU cycles determines the energy consumption.
Hence, the energy consumption of both fixed and power-only schemes, that fix the computation frequency allocation
at the highest value, is considerably increased with the increasing number of computation cycles. On the other hand, the energy consumption of both
CPU-only and proposed schemes with adjustable CPU frequencies do not change much as shown in Figs. 8-a and 8-b. As expected, using both transmit power and computation frequency allocation, our proposed schemes incur the least energy consumption for both small and large numbers of CPU cycles.
